characters: GUY, HIS BUDDIES, KIRSTEN, KRISTEN AND GIBBY, SIGN
WE FOCUS IN ON GUY, AS HE TAKES THE FRONT STEPS TWO AT A
YEARBOOKS, HANG OUT BY THE LOCKERS-
PULL OUT TO REVEAL HIM STANDING WITH JOSIE ON THE SIDEWAL
HANDS GRAB CHICAGO SUN TIMES AT THE NEWSSTAND-
JOSIE'S VOICE BEGINS TO FADE AWAY-
THE BASEBALL TEAM AS THEY PRACTICE-
ALDYS AND THE DENOMINATORS- MAKING SMORES OVER A BUNSON
"FINAL CAST LIST FOR HAMLET. HAMLET . . . ROB."
ROB TRYING TO SLOW DANCE WITH TRACY
BURNER GETTING INTO A MELTED CHOCOLATE AND MARSHMALLOW
"IMPEACH SYDNEY ANAKOWSKI. ELECT ROB STUDENT BODY PRESIDE
GUY, TOMMY AND JASON, AS THEY GET OUT GUY'S CAR, IN THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Josie Geller, 25, cute, blonde and scared out of her wits. We hear the chanting of a crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie! Josie! Josie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know in some movies how they  have a dream sequence only they  don't tell you it's a dream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL OUT to reveal Josie on pitcher's mound of a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's packed. Reporters line the field. All eyes are on  Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so not a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stadium clock sets at 5:00. The crowd goes crazy. Jos takes a deep, nervous breath and smiles, "Oh God."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple images of Josie play across rows of TV sets. A  crowd has gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't supposed to be like this.  I was just trying to do my job.  And then things happened. Well,  life happened. And now I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock starts to tick down. The crowd yells again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me. I am not the kind of  girl who does things like this. I  mean, two months ago you couldn't  have picked me out of a crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Packed with office workers. Bustling with activity. The  CAMERA searches the CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told you. I'm over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA SWINGS to Josie entering. Rhoda, a young copy  assistant, tails her, pen and paper in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theater--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standard American calls for "er".  Standard British is "re". So go  for "er", unless you're a pompous  American, then go for British.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie keeps negotiating the maze, leaving Rhoda in her  wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Theater. Last night. We were  supposed to go, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stops at a desk where Merkin Burns, officious offic assistant, is talking on the phone. He picks his nose wit abandon as he talks, ignoring Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) No way. No way. No way. Ech, hold  on. (to Josie) What.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Messages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merkin removes his finger from his nose and uses it to  pick up a pink message. He holds it out to Josie. Disgust she takes it by one corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Seriously? No way. No way--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's still standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merkin, do you think we could get  some more yellow highlighters? I  checked the box and we're--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merkin swivels his chair 180 degrees so his back is to  Josie and continues with his phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back into phone) Okay, I'm back, so--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie sighs, walks to her door. It's marked with a lopsid nameplate: Josie Geller, Copy Editor. She adjusts the pla so it's perfectly straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie enters, reads the messsage still gingerly held in  two fingers, and drops it into the trash can. She hangs  her coat squarely on the back of her door, takes five  pencils from her pencil pot, one by one sharpens them in  her pencil sharpener, and then lays them out neatly in a  row. She smiles, satisfied, ready for another day. Anita Brandt, late 20's, pretty in a semi-unprofessional  way, bursts in, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess who I did it with last  night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (duh) Roger in Op/Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did. Yesterday you said, and I  quote, "I have a date with Roger  from Op/Ed tonight and I'm going  to do it with him."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that doesn't mean it was  going to happen for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once it didn't happen for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus Strauss, late 30's, would probably clean up well,  enters. He tosses some copy onto Josie's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Computer's down. Septuplets story.  I need it back by five. Hopefully  the copy's not a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphasizing) It is hoped that it's not a mess.  "Hopefully" is an adverb. It means  "with hope". You have it defining  the copy, and I'm pretty sure the  copy doesn't have feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus and Anita just stare at Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, excuse me for caring about  words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Anita) So. You and Roger in Op/Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man! Who told?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger in Op/Ed. Don't make me send  you another memo about my policy  on inter-office dating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intra office. And they're not  dating. They're having sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is your policy? That if  you're not getting any, no one  can?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita flounces off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times have I fired her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five-- Six--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging, giving  up) Eh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus turns to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Gus--did you see the story  idea I left on your desk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah--the blind foster home mother.  It was good. I got Cahoon on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh. Cahoon. Yeah, he's--good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller, we've been over this. You're  a great copy editor. Maybe my best  copy editor. You're not a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done five of my ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what separates us office  flunkies from the reporters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have to be in the office  Christmas show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flack jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not getting it) A--flack jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Tom, Dick, and Harry thinks  he can write. But a journalist  gets in there, right where the  bombs are. He's aggressive. Grabs  the bull by the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I can grab bulls'  balls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller, you don't want a reporter's  life. They're very--messy. You're  all about order. Control. And  getting me my copy by five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--I can be out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus smiles. On his way out he re-adjusts Josie's nameplat so it hangs at an angle. Tormented, Josie waits a beat.  She can't take it, and runs to the door and straightens  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Copy by five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, a pretty depressing kitchenette area. Anita and Josie eat lunch--Anita eats Chinese out of a container,  Josie has three baggies of perfectly cut food in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be honest. Do you think I'm  aggressive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita ponders a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Remember when they took your  office chair in for repairs and  forgot to return it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stood for like a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia, an affable African-American woman in her 40's,  enters and puts three microwave meals in the microwave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because I'm not out of control  doesn't mean I can't write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, you listen to me. If you  feel you're a writer-- (touching her chest) Here, deep inside, don't let anyone  tell you you're not. Look at me.  Every day I come to this paper and  I pour my heart and soul into what  I do. I feel it, passionately, to  the core of my being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write obituaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you can make a busted aorta  sound good--honey, that's art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The microwave dings off. Cynthia fishes the three Lean  Cuisines out. Anita and Josie share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia, aren't they only diatetic  if you eat them one at a time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I eat 'em one at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Josie) Y'know, maybe Gus has a point. It  wouldn't kill you to relax and  have some fun. Roger's got a friend,  Marshall in editing? The one with  the lazy eye? Maybe we could double  date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God, Jos. When is the  last time you went on a real live  date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm concentrating on my career  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you own any colored underwear?  Stripes? Anything?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Anita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You're way under 30, you're  cute, some guys find white Carter's  underwear sexyВ— (beat) If you talk to his nose, you don't  even notice the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie laughs in spite of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right guy is out there. I'm  just not going to kiss a whole  bunch of losers to get to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but sometimes kissing the  losers can be a fun diversion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I finally get kissed, I'll  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita and Cynthia trade looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. If you've never kissed a  guy, we got bigger problems than  the underwear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've kissed guys. I've just never  kissed a guy. Felt that thing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That thing"? Is that what you  kids are calling it these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thing. That moment. You kiss  someone and it's like the world  around you gets all hazy and the  only thing in focus is you and  this other person and you know  that one person is the person you're  meant to be kissing for the rest  of your life. And for that one  moment you've been given this  amazing gift and you want to laugh  and cry at the same time because  you're so lucky you found it, and  so scared that it will all go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita and Cynthia take this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, girl. You are a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basically a Mailbox Etc. store, but dressed in a Tahitian theme. Cardboard hula dancers hold Fedex envelopes. ROB GELLER, 23, good-looking, wears a smock with "Tiki  Post" emblazoned across it over a Hawaiian shirt. He stan watch at the cash register. MONTY MAYLIK, 50, proud owner, rearranges a display. The  place is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Monty--you think we'll get any  business today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of course) I'm handing out a free lei to every  customer! What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe people are scared  off by the tiki torches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change is scary. Robbie, let me  tell you a little something about  the mail business. I've been in it  over thirty years. And in those  thirty years, the only thing that's  changed is the Elvis stamp and  some gun laws. People are bored!  They wanna shake things up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought people just wanted their  mail delivered on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks into the store, triggering Hawaiian music.  Monty puts a lei over her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha! Welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax, Monty. It's just my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monty takes the lei off her neck. Josie hands Rob an  envelope. Rob rifles through the cash inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jos. I'll pay you back.  Bambi thanks you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob indicates a beat-up wreck of a yellow car parked  outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so--weird that you name  your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not. Guys name their  penises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okaaaay.... (then) That car's going to bankrupt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just needs a new windshield  wiper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I bought the windshield  last week. I'm a hubcap away from  owning more of Bambi than you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob hands the money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know what? Take it. I don't want  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie hands it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob, take the money, okay? It's no  big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it is. It's just one more thing  to add to your "things that make  you a better person than me" list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better person than I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this woman. She works in  admissions at Lakeshore Community?  She might be able to get you in  for the Fall semester. Maybe she  could get you the baseball  scholarship, and I could help and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to college, Jos. And  I'm not playing anymore baseball.  This is my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) This--this is a luau that sells  packing material!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday this luau is going to be  all mine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you just give up like that?  You had a real shot at playing  college ball and you let one case  of mono stop everything. Don't you  want more? To move out of Mom and  Dad's? Pay your own bills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yay! And then I could be as  happy as you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your information, I am very  happy. Deliriously happy. I lead a  very happy life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits. The music starts up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN AROUND the neatest and quietest walk-up you've eve seen. Lots of books on shelves. We find Josie sitting at her small table putting the  finishing touches on a needlepoint pillow. She turns it  over and WE SEE it says: "LOVE". She holds up the final  product to a terrarium, lookup up at her two turtles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. What d'you think, guys?  Where should it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie looks around the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm. (She pretends to  listen to the  turtles.) What's that? Bedroom? Great idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into the bedroom with the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfectly arranged Laura Ashley bedroom. We PAN OVER TO the bed. It is completely covered in needlepoint pillows. Josie places the latest one on top of the others and smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's packed with the NEWSPAPER STAFF. HYRAM RIGFORT, 65,  white-haired, dignified owner of the paper presides. Anit and Josie sit next to each other. Next to Anita sits Roge from Op/Ed, a good-looking guy in his 30's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me start out by saying that I  was very impressed by the  investigative piece Dutton did on  pesticides in our supermarkets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older man, Dutton, smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But since the Trib did a better  piece on the same subject, you're  fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutton's face falls. Everyone looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me. Out. Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutton shuffles out. Josie takes a big bite of donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Happy March everybody!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (by rote) Happy March Mr. Rigfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To celebrate, I've decided it's  time for another undercover feature!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks underwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know that some of my best  inspiration comes from personal  experience. Who knew that my botched  foray into hair plugs would lead  to last month's award-winning expose --  "hair today, gone tomorrow"? Hat's  off to you, Bruns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN OVER to BRUNS, a reporter whose hair is missing in odd-looking clumps. He nods sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or should I say "hat's on"! And  what about when my wife had that  affair with Gil, her ski instructor  and Howard went undercover as an  expert slalom skier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard smiled wanly. Both his arms are in casts. CAMERA  PANS the room as Rigfort continues, picking out different reporters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So last night I'm sitting around  the dinner table with my family.  The wife, the two nannies, the  boys, and we're eating chicken  with this peanut sauce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS at a Chef Boyardee look-alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undercover chef. I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, Gus. So, we're eating  this peanut sauce and suddenly the  younger kid starts choking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS at a Nurse Ratchet look-alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto to Josie) I'm smelling undercover ER nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turns out he's allergic to peanuts.  And I think -- holy shit. I don't  even know my own kids. I mean, who  knows if they're even mine? And it  got me thinking. How much do we  know about kids today? What are  they thinking? How many of them  are allergic to peanuts? Boom. It  hit me -- "My Semester In High  School."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA STOPS at a bald guy, the jerks over one seat to  Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Josie) You. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie. Josie Geller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You enroll on Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General crowd hubub. Josie's in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. But--I'm not a reporter yet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And none of these geezers could  pass for a day under 40. Have fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Rigfort exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie is so excited she can hardly speak to Anita.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's finally happening, Anita! I'm  going to write!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own undercover feature - "Written  by Josie Geller".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jos - Maybe you should turn it  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Josie's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No - It's just a lot of pressure  for your first piece, that's all.  I mean, it's not a half-page  article, it's a major undercover  piece, Jos. Look what Rigfort did  to Dutton - and that guy's his  cousin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, I'll straighten all  this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want it straightened  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller, this is way out of your  league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie takes in Anita and Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, just so I'm clear here --  neither of you think I can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jos, that's not what we're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita, when you wanted to seduce  the guy in the mailroom and you  didn't think you could learn Spanish  fast enough, who quizzed you on  your verbs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita looks down, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senorita Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Gus - when you picked up  knitting, who showed you how to  hold the needles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) YOU DID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gus) YOU KNIT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, this is my chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not holding your job for you,  Geller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie jumps up and down and hugs Gus, who is clearly  uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me send you the memo on  hugging in the workplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles. Gus exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do believe in you, Jos. Anything  you need, I'll help you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie sits, motions to the brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can start by handing me that  bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita does. Josie sticks it over her face, flips her head between her knees and starts hyperventilating again. CLOSE UP on Rob, wearing his Tiki Post outfit. He shakes  his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Uh, uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's shiny Buick is parked right behind Bambi at the  curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just for a couple of months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't just "borrow" my car for  a couple of months! That's like  ten years in Bambi life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you my Buick Le Sabre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob rolls his eyes and enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can name it whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie follows Rob into the store. He turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. This must be big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got an assignment from the paper.  I'm going undercover. Back to high  school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob starts laughing uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember high school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a long time ago -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you remember what they called  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly Josie's face falls. She looks very far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's packed with kids. Everyone stares off-screen at chan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie Grossie. Josie Grossie. Josie  Grossie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie looks stricken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie Grossie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I came up with it. (beat) You look nauseous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nauseated. I look nauseated. Oh  God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts her hand over her mouth, races for the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie has just gotten violently ill. She rises off her  knees, grabs some toilet paper to wipe her mouth. She loo down at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We CLOSE UP on brown leather oxfords and widen to reveal  teenage JOSIE braces, heavy glasses, in all her nerdom, slowly walking  down the corridor with a huge backpack on her back. A boy sneaks up behind her, holds open the top of her  backpack while another boy pours a half drunk Sprite into her backback. Kids smile and snicker as Josie continues down the hallwa She spots, BILLY PRINCE, ultmate high school heartthrob,  and approaches him nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy Prince, I noticed you  weren't in math today, and I have  the notes in case you want -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midway through Josie's speech, WE HEAR the odd sound of  liquid hitting linoleum. Josie follow Billy's gaze down t between her feet where a pool of Sprite has gathered. Bil starts to laugh. Kids around him join in. As the laughter echoes around her we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stares into the mirror. Staring back is teenage Jos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita and Josie cruise through a teen clothing store,  carrying large bags from a stationery store. Josie picks  up a platform sneaker and just stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you were a geek. Big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita, remember espadrilles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. That doesn't make you a  nerd. Everyone wore those shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls threw them at me in the  locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. That's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the yeat the person  who got the most direct his to my  head got to toss me into the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama mia. (then) Just because you were a nerd once  doesn't mean it's going to happen  again. That's why you have me for  fashion consultation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita pulls a slip skirt off a rack and holds it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is lingerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I was thinking about what you  were saying - y'know, about really  being kissed? I think Roger could  be the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you feel when you kissed  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bridgework?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie pulls out a plain button-down cardigan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not letting you out of the  house in that, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita grabs an awful white maribou jacket and matching  earrings and holds them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuuuute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Nita, this is about reporting,  not accessorizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're going to have to do  something about your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jos, please try and have some fun  here, okay? How many of us get to  go back to high school? You're  gonna have a blast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: on a bedside table. Surrounded by make-up, boxes of hair  color, a stack of index cards, ripped magazine pages of  teen looks, issues of Teen Beat and YM. The clock slips t 7:00. NPR starts playing. A hand reaches over, hits the  radio off. SOUND EFFECTS: A school bell. As the bell continues to  ring, we WIDEN TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie sits up in bed, covers pulled up to her chin in  terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: "Morning Train". Crowds of commuters stream dow the sidewalk and onto the stairs leading up to the El. A big yellow car jerks into frame, backfires noisily. It' Josie at the wheel of Bambi. She jerks out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suburban campus anchored by a main building. Cars pull  into the parking lot for the beginning of the day. Kids  greet each other, converge on the front doors of the scho General mayhem. Bambi pulls in. She jerks into a spot, backfiring once  more for effect. The entire scene stops. Kids freeze, loo at Josie. A beat, and they they continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie takes a few deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I can do this. Piece of cake.  I can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie steps out of the car wearing the maribou jacket,  earrings, and white jeans. She shuts the door behing her, starts walking. She has unknowingly shut her jacket in th door and as she walks, a piece of maribou rips, trailing  behind her like a tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Feeling good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie merges with the throngs of kids and is literally  pushed into the lobby. She stares around, overwhelmed. "G Rams!" banners share space with signs that read: "63 DAYS TIL PROM!" She inches her way along the wall until she is stopped by a guard who grabs her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm a student. Most definitely  a student. In high school. Here. I  am going to class. With my fellow  students. (greeting random  kids) Hi. Hi there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard stares at her a beat and then motions behind  them, to three huge metal detectors that the kids are  filtering through. Josie smiles, "whoops," walks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's stuff lays out on the post-detector table - cell  phone, laptop, mini tape recorder, electronic organizer,  pager, being scrutinized by the guard. Josie's sure she's been found out. CAMERA WIDENS. Down from Josie, WE SEE  other kids' belongings spread out. They have the identica high-tech equipment. The guard picks up Josie's nail file examines it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And throws it in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stares at her class card and eyes the classrooms,  totally lost. She approaches a boy in a flannel shirt and loose jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi--um, I'm looking for Room 204,  Ms. Knox?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as the boy starts to talk, we notice something in his mouth - a tongue pierce. Josie does too. We ZOOM IN o that shiny little metal ball. Josie is fixated. So fixate that we stop hearing the boy's voice. All WE SEE is the  mouth - and that ball - moving. The mouth closes. He's  done. Josie's face is contorted in imagined pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow. (catching herself) I mean, wow. Wow. Great directions.  Clear. Concise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Josie takes off, totally embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks up to Room 204. Opening the door, she's met b a sea of faces. MS. KNOX, mid-forties, distracted but bubbly, sits in the front of the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi - hello. Wilkommen. Entre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks in. Kids whisper and snicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I'm sorry I forgot to  take my hot flash medication this  morning. Josie, right? Please sit.  Mi casa es su casa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie makes her way to the desk, trailing maribou. The  class titters. She sits in front of two girls, KIRSTEN an KRISTEN, beautiful and intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is so sad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, like five chickens had to  die just so she could look that  stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, in my classroom, tardiness  is unacceptable --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Knox pulls a ridiculously huge sombrero out from unde her desk. The class laughs in recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as sorry as I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Knox puts the sombrero on a less-than-thrilled Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ole! Ten minutes in this hat, you'll  never be late again. So, let's  hear something about you. Stand  up. Stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie does. The sombrero drops over her eyes. She adjusts it so she can read her notecards. CLOSE UP on the notecard --it's filled with precise scrip under a heading: MY PAST.  She scans it, then flips the cards face-down on the desk. Confidently she begins --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Josie. I'm a high school  student. I came from --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then the classroom door opens. WE SEE from Josie's  perspective a blinding light, Josie squints. From the lig emerges a shadowy vision of Billy Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie blinks, REVEAL not Billy, but a beautiful guy, Guy. He stands very close to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (catching herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another beat) I'm from Billy-Bali. It's a suburb  of Bali proper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy pushes past her, tosses a wooden hall pass to Ms. Kno and moves to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bali. Fascinating! What did your  family do there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie looks around in panic, sees a student in a South  Glen South windbreaker with huge ram on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were--sheep--farmers. We raised  sheep. In Billy-Bali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie realizes the trouble she's gotten herself into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. (caught) Oh my God--do I miss Billy-Bali. (beat) It had--a really great...aquarium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits. Defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie rushes down the hall, still toting her enormous bag A huge banner - SOUTH GLEN, OUR NATION'S BEST PROM - hang prominently. She talks covertly into a hand-held tape  recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note to self--Research Bali. Kill  Anita for picking out this outfit.  Find and destroy sombrero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie and her enormous bookbag enter. She takes a seat  toward the back of the room. Kristen, Kirsten and GIBBY, another beauty, enter and hea to the back of the room. Kirsten and Gibby stand over Josie, staring at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry--I didn't know these  were assigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie quickly gathers her things and moves one row forwar next to two empty seats. TWO STONERS shuffle over to Josi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. We sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating two  empty seats) Couldn't you two--sit there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Except there are three of  us--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stoners eye each other, then the two seats. A look of horror comes over Stoner 1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude--we left Jed at the 7-11! (beat) Again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie picks up her stuff, moves to the last empty seat in the room-in the front row, surrounded by "" who all wear  orange Denominator sweatshirts. Sitting next to Josie is ALDYS, a Denominator--intense,  wise, with a whole bunch of math medals on her sweatshirt She smiles at Josie. Josie smiles back and looks up as MR. COULSON enters the  room. He's a ruggedly handsome twenty-something Yale grad He grabs a notebook out of his bag, goes around to sit on the front of his desk, sipping coffee from a Styrofoam  cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, everyone. (Spots Josie) I don t think we've met. I'm Sam  Coulson- although for some reason  the school has this thing about  not letting you guys call me Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shyly) I'm Josie. Geller. I think the  school would probably be pretty  comfortable with you calling, me  that. Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie since you're new--I love to  drink my coffee during class, and  since I allow myself to do this, I  allow everyone to bring beverages  to class as well. (a beat) welcome to Shakespeare's "As You  Like It." (beat) Okay. How many of you actually  read the assignment last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About five hands go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. Now how many of you spent  more than thirty minutes eating  salty snack foods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty hands. Sam laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man. If I could just get you guys  to read while you eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam opens his book. Aldys notices Josie has no book. She  moves next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. We can share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'As You Like It" is an example of  a Shakespearean--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam turns to the blackboard and starts writing. We CU on  his butt, hardly discernable in his loose 501 jeans, all  the girls swoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pastoral Comedy. Anyone know what  that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enthusiastic, if slightly dim girl, SERA, waves her  hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh oh oh! That's what they do to  milk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pasteurize, Sera. But close.  Same letter-- (tapping three  fingers on his arm  a la charades) --three syllables--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parakeet?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto to Josie) There's a minute of my life I'll  never get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, anyone else---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie can't contain herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pastoral means set in the country.  Originally seen in the Eclogues of  Virgil. It's from the Latin pascere.  To graze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Student bleets like a sheep O.S. Sam just stares at her,  smiling. Finally, he walks over and shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I mention to the class that I  love our new student?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I mention that the class also  loves our new kiss ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's smile quickly fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibby, that's not exactly the kind  of participation I'm looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibby looks right at Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally insincere) Ooops. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie just sits there, face burning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie approaches her locker. She can't get to it because COUPLE is busy making out against it. A GIRL'S VOICE comes over the loudspeaker. She's complete ignored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. This is Sydney, Student Body  President!  Okay, first. Bad news- The' district didn't allocate enough  funds, so as of this afternoon,  there will be no music department.  Now, about Prom--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire hallway FREEZES. The couple breaks their clinc and looks up. SILENCE. Josie is amazed. SYDNEYВ’S VOICE Voting on Prom theme has been  completed. And the theme is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on expectant FACES. SYDNEYВ’S VOICE The Millennium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PANDEMONIUM. Kids cheer, gasp. One GIRL faints. The crowd surges again. Josie, caught in the flow, doesn' notice a locker door flinging open. She smashes her face  right into it. Everyone, including Guy, turns and laughs. Even some Denominators.

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: Moves down the food line. It's piled with unidentifiable  foods and three glasses of fluorescent red punch. Hands  pull the tray out of the frame. INTO FRAME comes another  tray, this one bearing a perfectly arranged place setting with three celery sticks on a plate. WIDEN TO REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, pulling the perfect tray down the cafeteria line.  She reaches some awful-looking Cole slaw in a big vat. A  CAFETERIA GUY in a plastic cap hovers above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cafeteria guy) Excuse me. What's in the Cole slaw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cafeteria guy hauls an industrial-size plastic tub  onto the, counter and turns it-so Josie can read the labe "KOLE SLAW FOOD."  Josie wrinkles her nose. She moves on  to the cash register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be twelve ninety-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh. Wow. That's... pricey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's real meat in the ham  sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie turns to a GIRL in line behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy--that's a lot of bread for  that bread!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girl rolls her eyes, reaches past Josie to grab a  mustard bottle. Josie turns with her tray toward the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 KIDS stare at CAMERA and chant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie Grossie--Josie Grossie--Josie  Grossie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE BACK ON JOSIE. She's seventeen. Standing with her  tray, paralyzed. The CAMERA SPINS, showing us her back.  There, tattooed in squeeze-bottle mustard, is "GROSSIE." A boy stands behind her victoriously holding the mustard  bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie shakes off the vision and stares out at the crowded cafeteria. She sees Kirsten, Kristen and Gibby, steels  herself, and decides to approach. Kirsten is eating a bran muffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten, that bran muffin has like  75 fat grams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah uh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I read this thing that one  bran muffin can be like two bran  muffins sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kirsten pushes the muffin away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God. Food is so confusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kirsten) Hi Kristen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Kirsten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie plops herself down with these girls, and takes a  spiral pad out of her big knapsack. In the process, she  manages to spill her chocolate milk all over her white  jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll teach me to wear white  after Labor Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm- I don't think you're supposed  to wear white jeans after 1983.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh. Josie fakes a laugh, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie picks up her notepad and her pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - tell me about yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all just stare at Josie in disgust. Guy approaches  their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy looks at Josie. He's beautiful. She's flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you are. A guy. Guy. Quite a  guy. Oh my. Look at that--I rhymed. (beat) Yikes. (beat) Bikes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very serious) Are you in special ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stands up, grabs her bag and her chocolate milk -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. Guy. Others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the Cafeteria, passing a-couple of Denominator

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Aaaah! How old am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approximately six thousand three  hundred and fifty days old-subject  to adjustment for month of birth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is very funny Denominator humor- to the Denominators Josie leaves the Cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie runs out an exit door and right into a SECURITY GUA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a pass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A banner above reads "PRESIDENTIAL FITNESS TESTING THIS  WEEK." FIFTEEN SENIOR GIRLS, including Josie, in matching green and yellow polyester gym clothes do sprints up and- down the basketball court. Josie looks like she's about t die. Ms. Brown yells as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: move it Geller! Move it! Move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stops, grabs the woman by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must--have--water--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I look like, your waitress?  Now you're gonna complete these  sprints, cause if you don't you  fail. And if you fail gym, you're  NEVER GETTING INTO COLLEGE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--my--God--you guys areВ—still  telling that lie--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it Geller--drop and give me  twenty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie drops to the gym floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's - finally- the end of the day. Josie makes her way  down the hall, clutching her pad of paper, getting pushed and shoved by kids as they storm outside. A huge banner  hangs overhead reading: "SIGN UP FOR SENIOR NIGHT!" She tries to smile at some kids, but they all ignore her. She makes it to the main entrance to the school, where we see, as she shoves her pad of paper into her bag, it is  completely blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids fill the parking lot. Josie walks, talking on her  cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Rhoda, make sure Gus gets-the whole  message, okay? Yeah--bye--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie arrives where she parked Bambi. The space is empty. She still holds the phone to her ear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second-- (into phone) No, not you--bye--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie shuts the phone, looks around...retraces her steps  ... Bambi is gone. Josie walks around the lot, getting visibly upset. In the corner of the lot, WE SEE a group of Denominators  removing a BIG METAL CHAIN from around a group of tightly packed cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do it to all the new kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie finds Aldys standing next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's of they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys motions up to a second floor window. Guy and his  Group look down on them, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy Perkins and his amazing  Lemmings. They push your car out  of its space, hide it, then watch  while you look for it. We've taken  to chaining ours together for  safety. I'm Aldys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Josie. Aldys is an interesting  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it's not yours. My mom was  going through her Harlequin Romance  phase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try being named after a guitar- playing pussycat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys doesn't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. (beat) That is so awful that they hide  your cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: guess. Although, what is truly  awful is that with the combined  intellectual effort of every kid  in that room right now-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points up to the biology room-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still would not know the  difference between a synecdoche  and a hyperbole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys stares Josie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Synecdoche uses a part to represent  a whole- as in " head of cattle",  whereas a hyperbole is simple  exaggeration like "I could eat a  horse."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop and look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will they watch us for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until Guy tells them to go. Once  they watched me for like two hours.  I found my car the next day in the  T.J. Maxx parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do they listen to Guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (duh) Because he's Guy Perkins. (then) Listen, you want to walk to Na- Na's and get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to walk out of the parking lot. Josie is visib thrilled - having finally found a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie and Aldys share a huge plate of chili fries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - isn't it amazing that those  guys are our same age? I mean,  they just seem so much younger,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WAITER delivers two huge chocolate shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be so happy to get to  college. I hear at Northwestern  they don't make fun of you for  knowing the element table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--I went to Northwestern! (a beat) Once. To use the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUT THE WINDOW, Josie sees her Buick with Rob at the whee stopped at a red light. Detailed on to the side in big  white script is: "THE TIKI POST".  Josie's eyes widen. The light changes. Rob pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (So angry) Oh. My. God. (a beat) You'll really like Northwestern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both slurp down their shakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are your hopes, your dreams,  what do you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor of medieval literature.  Novelist. Weekend flautist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys takes another slurp of her shake. WE HEAR a muffled cell phone RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think your knapsack is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie takes the cell phone out of her knapsack and answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus speaks into his phone, knitting frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller, I got your message. What  the hell kind of story are you  pitching?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles awkwardly at Aldys, covering the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my dad. He worries. (into phone) Hi, Dad. I miss you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sick puppy, Geller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie indicates to Aldys she'll be right back and walks t the back of the restaurant by the pay phones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) It's an expose on cafeteria food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're leading with the terrible  truth about cole slaw?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the bulk of it will be about  the pimento loaf--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geller...you wanna be a reporter?  Take a look at what sells! Sex  scandals. Bribery. People jumping  off buildings. So unless a kid  just killed himself because he was  being paid to have sex with the  school mascot in a big vat of this  cole slaw, you got nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus slams down his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into a dead phone) You didn't taste the pimento loaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks back to the table where Aldys is dividing the  check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of the track is Josie's car. The MARCHING  BAND clumsily practices their formations around it. Josie and Aldys arrive at the car and Aldys pops the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love to disconnect the battery,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks under the hood, reconnects the battery. Slams  the hood down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you know, I think they  recalled these cars in 1974.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys heads to the lot for her car, and then turns around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Josie, how are you at Calculus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to join The  Denominators? The Math Team could  really use a new brain. We lost  our best logarithm guy last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: College?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NASA. (beat) Plus we have these really fun pizza  study groups, and we go to-these  all county meets. And, I mean, not  that you need it, and without  sounding too much like the  Godfather, I think we could offer  you a certain amount of protection",  if you know what I mean. We all  kind of stick together and watch  out for each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles.  MUSIC UP: SCHOOL HOUSE ROCK'S "Magic Three"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie and Denominators walk down the hallway in unison,  past Guy's Group, open their lockers in order a la  "RESERVOIR DOGS", take out paper, pencils, calculators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie and Aldys, both wearing big orange Denominator  sweatshirts, are behind a table manning a bake sale. A banner behind them says: n = 3.14578697786978 Pie = $.7 No one is stopping to buy anything. Josie points to the  left, Aldys looks, and Josie stuffs a whole brownie in he mouth. They laugh uncontrollably as Josie starts to choke and cough up most of the brownie. We PAN DOWN a row of nervous looking Denominator faces as they watch Josie, sitting head to head against a DIGIT, a opposing Math-a-lon competitor. They both work furiously  on a problem. A judge sits between them. A makeshift  scoreboard hanging off the desk shows the score is tied. Josie bangs the bell on the desk and hands the judge her  card. He looks it over, and gives her team five points.  They win. The Denominators erupt into cheers. They're jumping all  over Josie, going crazy. As we go wider we see the gym is entirely empty, except for a handful of Denominators goin crazy on one side, and a janitor sweeping up on the other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling at each other, Josie and Aldys clutch books  excitedly and stand in line. WE WIDEN to reveal they're i line with NERDY ADULTS also clutching their books. At the head of the line is a blow-up poster for The New Elements Of Grammar. An OLD MAN signs books for his fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late. Josie is typing on her laptop, referencing not from her notebook. Schoolbooks and homework are spread  around her. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam is perched on the desk. The usual players in their  usual seats. Aldys is standing and reading from her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "All the world's a stage and all  the men and women merely players."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone have any idea what  Shakespeare meant by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone? Sera ... Megan ... exchange  student who doesn't speak English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We CU on the students, ending on an Asian boy who smiles  wildly at Sam and waves. Sam smiles, and waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about disguise, playing a  part. It's the theme of "As You  Like It." Can anyone tell me where  we see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Rosalind disguises herself  as a man and escapes into the  forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And it's when she's in  costume that she can finally express  her love for Orlando. See,  Shakespeare's making the point  here that when we're disguised, we  feel freer. We can do things we  wouldn't do in ordinary life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on Josie's face. She's clearly uncomfortable. Sam walk up to a huge football player, BRETT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brett when you go out on the  football field in your uniform,  what happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit people. You yell. You touch  other guys' butts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class giggles. Brett looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's okay, because you're in  uniform. Disguise changes the rules (beat) I had these Spiderman pyjamas. I  thought when I wore them, that I  had super powers. One night I tried  to walk up the side of the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the Emergency Room. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles at this, a little smitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, why don't you read from Act  5, Scene 2, Rosalind's speech--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stands up, starts reading--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No sooner had they met but they  looked; no sooner looked but they  loved; no sooner loved but they  sighed..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE BACK to Josie, now seventeen and mortified, nervous standing in class and reading a poem. Billy Prince sits t the side--she glances at him throughout the poem, it's  clearly about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he notice me? Does he hear my  heart screaming his name-- sometimes  it's so loud I think the Gods can  hear my pain. His voice is so  mellifluous, oh to get just one  small kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLASS laughs at her except for Billy, who smiles at  her, looking slightly touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventeen-year-old Josie is surrounded by an elaborate,  color-coded index card system for her research paper. Her friend, SHEILA, over-weight and pimply, comes running across the library at breakneck speed. She sits down next to Josie, visibly excited and pushes her index cards asid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., what have you wanted for  like ever but you didn't think it  would -ever happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie looks at her for a moment, mulling it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That they'd start an Olympic team  for grammar - like diagramming  sentences and verb declensions and  stuff. And I'm scouted for the  team- just as an alternate, of  course- because I'm so young. But  then there's talk of me in the '96  games-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-, better. Something better

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the most popular girl in school,  and Billy Prince is taking me to  prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie laughs at the absurdity. She looks at Sheila. Sheil is dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Prince is asking you to prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) The poem! I knew he liked the poem! (all sinking in) Billy Prince is asking me to the  prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two girls look at each other. Big smiles erupt into  screams, as they jump up and down, hugging each other. SFX - The BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: It's the end of class. Students pack their bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) O.K. - just a reminder. Your paper  is due in one week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys and Josie head out of class and down the hallway  towards their lockers. Josie stops in front of hers where the Makeout Couple continues their clinch, blocking her  locker. Josie pauses frustrated as Sydney's Voice comes  over the loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey guys! Bad news--Chem wing is  closed. The Hazardous Materials  Crew is on the way. Now, about  prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire hallway STOPS to listen. The makeout Couple  stop making out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please join a committee--because  we are going to KICK NORTHGLEN'S  BUTT and make millennium the best  prom EVER!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway erupts in CHEERS. Josie makes a move to go fo her locker. The Makeout Couple are faster. They're back i their clinch, blocking Josie again.

dialogues.speaker: CU ON GUY
dialogues.text: walking with his group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rufus! Prom is gonna be Rufus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rufus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I made it up. Start using  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is with this school and prom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Southglen South competes every  year for best prom, and usually  they win. We Denominators don't  even go to prom. -But to everyone  else it's huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys, don't miss your prom--it  only happens once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one has been so hyped. We're  tied for most wins with Northglen  North. This year's winner will  determine the winner of the century.   The theme is everything. So whatever  Southglen picks has to be totally  unique--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KIDS all stare at a loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this year's prom theme is--the  millennium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Northglen kids go crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie reaches for her knapsack, and realizes she left it  in English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left my bag in English. I'll see  you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie dashes down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam still sits at his desk. He reads a book. Josie enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa. Deja Vu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Forgetful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie picks up her bookbag. She notices the book Sam's  reading--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Dorothy Parker--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the way she writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the happiest of souls. (reading out of  book) "Art is a form of catharsis, and  love is a permanent flop."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I think she wanted to be happy,  that's why she wrote. I mean, she  was still writing about love, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True. I guess she hadn't completely  given up hope. (then) Are you sure you're seventeen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because seventeen-year-olds do not  like writers from the '30's. They  don't even like people in their  30's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm definitely seventeen and (off clock) now definitely late--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she smiles and runs out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys drives, Josie has shotgun and TYKE, Aldys' nine-yea old sister, is in back. They all hold double-scooped cone and they all sing FREE TO BE YOU AND ME at full voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, aren't you guys glad you took  a break from that Denominator stuff.  I mean, you shouldn't be spending  your Saturday night studying the  whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: we should be spending it thinking  of how we can better serve your  baby-sitting needs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pull up at a red light, next  to an abandoned drive-in. Josie  peers in, and sees a BIG GROUP OF  KIDS, standing around a bonfire  drinking beers, talking, a few  making out. She opens her window,  sticks her head out, and tries to  get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the old drive-in. They call  it "The Court". Now it's just a  continuous party for Guy's group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: Gibby and Kristen talking by a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder what they talk  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, what if they just stupid  to hide the fact that they're  actually brainiacs with super powers  and they're plotting to take over  the world and make my life hell  until I die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's lather, rinse, repeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Guy pokes his head in, startling everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, if it isn't Alpo. Coming out  to sniff some hydrants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie is frozen, but not Aldys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Guy, you on a little break  from having an original thought?  Ooops, I forgot, that's all the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyke gets it, and laughs. Guy doesn't get it at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys aren't seriously trying  to hang out at The Court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oooh, cheap wine coolers and a  fire in a trashcan. Where do I  sign up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stay away from prom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last I checked--this was still a  free country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) There's a land that I see, where  the children are free-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's right in Aldys' face, leaning over Josie. Aldys sta to drive away. Guy keeps his head in the window while he  runs alongside the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, geek, why don't you just go  home and play with your calculator.  Figure out how many lifetimes it  will take you to get cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy stops running, and the car continues down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aldys seems a little shaken, Tyke continues singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever wanted to go to The  Court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, Josie? It's lame.  All they do is stand around and  get drunk. It's lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's lame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it sounds lame. Why would we  want to go there, and stand around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a newspaper headline: "THE COURT - SITE FOR  PARTIES, DRUGS AND WEEKEND ARRESTS" - as Gus throws the  newspaper down on his desk. Josie sits across the desk from him. She reads the headli looking very surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, I am appalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie picks up the paper, and starts reading intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, so am I. I had no idea that  these kids- let's see- turn to A14-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to turn to A14, but Gus grabs the paper out of  her hands in a rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to keep his  cool) No, I am appalled that I have a  reporter in there, undercover, for  almost three weeks now- I had to  read about this in the Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus angrily tries to fold the paper back 'up. He's having a hard time. Josie tries to help, but he yanks it away.  Gus reads aloud from the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Responding officers found minors,  marijuana, and cheap wine coolers  when they responded to a call to  break up a party at what Southglen  High Schoolers have come to call  "The Court." Seventeen-year-old  Kristen Rey says, "Yeah, everyone  who's anyone is at The Court on  Saturday night."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) Kristen got a quote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus looks up at Josie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, urm, she's right. I have  learned it is a very popular place  for the young people to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to any parties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how would you define to  parties"? Because we ordered a  deli platter at this one Denominator  drill session--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus looks like he may combust. He opens the newspaper,  finds what he's looking for, and shoves it in Josie's fac It is a picture of all of the popular kids at Southglen-  Kristen, Kirsten, Gibby, Guy- they are all posing for the picture at The Court, smiling and holding beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where the stories are. You  are going to become friends with  these people. You are going to  party with them. You are going to  hang out with them on weekends.  When they go to prom, you are going  to be in their same damn limo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus I, the popular kids and I, we  just don't- I mean, I don't think  I can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the picture in the paper of the Popular Kids

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even know these kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying) They hid my car--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus leans in very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get to know them. Very well. Your  job and my job depends on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very small) Depend on it. No s. Your subject  is plural.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie grabs her knapsack and does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie runs through the bullpen, past Anita's cubicle. ROG from op/ed enters. He and Anita smile flirtatiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Roger from op/ed--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Anita from classifieds. We still  on for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: of course--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he leans in and kisses her. She pulls away, confused. A beat. Anita kisses him again. Nothing. ANITA (CONTВ’D) (can't believe she's  saying it--) Y'know what? No, I don't think we  are on. I think I have to stay  home. (liking how it sounds) Yeah. I'm staying home! I don't  know what I'll do there, but I'm  gonna do it. Alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under) Freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob opens the door still dressed in his Tiki Post outfit. He takes one look at Josie and knows that things are not  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are mom and dad here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They're at the Franklin Hint  Expo at the Skokie Holiday Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoves her way into the house. Rob follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie storms into the den, and plants herself on the sofa She sees that Rob has been watching baseball on T.V., and she turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it. I thought I could.  I can't. I give up--I'm never going  to be a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob sits next to her on the couch. He looks up at the T.V which is now off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you catch the score?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie gives him a look of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean, no big whoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls the article out of her purse, and shoves it at  Rob. He sees the picture of all the popular kids at The  Court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These girls are high schoolers?  Damn, we've got some underage  hotties on our hands, here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus insists that I become friends  with these kids. The popular kids.  It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that impossible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's eyes get teary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob, you don't know how it was for  me back in high school. No one  ever threw juice boxes at you in  the hallway. You never dreamed  about being popular- you already  were. All I wanted was to be  accepted, and they just fucking  tortured me. I can't do all that  again. I can't go back to Southglen  South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! You're at Southglen  South? They have a killer baseball  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob. Please focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jos, you've been to college, you're  successful, you wash your hair now--  you're not Josie Grossie anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you realize how much I wanted  to be you in high school? Just for  one minute to feel what it was  like to be popular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! It's not that hard. All  you need is one person. Once the  right person thinks you're cool,  you're in. Everyone else will be  too scared to question it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little known fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
