dialogues.text: Sam smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're amazing, Josie Geller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: GUY AND ALDYS as they dance, WE SEE the Cool  Girls and Jason standing to the side of the dance floor  laughing Gibby reaches into her purse and pulls out a CAN OF ALPO. She hands it to Jason who pulls a CAN OPENER out of his pocket, opens the lid. He hands it to Kirsten who  take the lid off. She hands the can to Kristen, who hands the can to Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So--have you thought anymore about  Dartmouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on Josie's HAND as she subtlety removes her hidd camera pin and drops it to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I have to tell  you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her foot comes down on top of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is making out with his Date when the monitor sudde FRITZES OFF. George looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the--?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stands and hits the side of the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus's monitor flicks to static. The Crowd lets out a  horrified GASP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him what?! Tell him what?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks deep into Josie's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something I have to tell  you, too--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie's eyes shift from Sam to over his shoulder. She spo Aldys, who smiles at her. Josie's eyes travel up to the  can of DOG FOOD.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: on the porch, facing Billy and his Date.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH
dialogues.text: with egg dripping all over her. BACK TO PRESENT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOOOOOOO!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW MOTION as Josie lunges for Aldys and pulls her to  floor as Tommy, off-balance, dumps the dog food all down  Guy's front. The Crowd stops dead, staring. The can, now  empty, rolls slowly off the dance floor, the metal rollin noise ECHOING in the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Josie) What is your problem?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. You are a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruined the whole thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You so do not deserve to be prom  queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is still staring. It's dead quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is still silent. Josie takes a deep breath, and looks  around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care about being the prom  queen. I am twenty five years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks of confusion and teenage disgust. Rob is pissed. Sa looks shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here as an undercover reporter  for the Sun Times for God's sake  and I've been beating my brains  out trying to impress you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tears off her crown, and chucks it. She's on a roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to tell you something. You  people- Guy, Gibby, the rest of  you who have been keeping the geeks  down through the ages. You will  spend your lives trying to figure  out ways to keep others down,  because it makes you feel more  important. And you will miss out  on so much. (indicating Aldys) Why her, huh?  What did she ever  do to you? Let me tell you something  about this girl. She is  unbelievable. I was new here, and  she befriended me- no questions  asked. But you people, you were my  friends only after my brother,  Rob...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points out Rob in the crowd. He's mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: posed as a student and told you to  like me. But y'know--l have to  thank you. I got to go to an amazing  prom. I got to be prom queen. I  got to be cool. It felt good. (beat) But not as good as being myself. (turns to crowd) And to all of you-- there's a big  world out there. Bigger than prom.  Bigger than high school. When you  get there, it won't matter if you  were prom queen or the quarterback  or the biggest nerd in school.  What matters is that you don't  regret who you were, who you are- What if Steven Spielberg had quit  the audio/visual club because it  wasn't "cool"? What if Rosie  O'Donnell had stopped cracking  jokes because someone told her  they were stupid?  What if Michael  Jordan never went back to basketball  after he got cut from his high  school team?. (a beat) In this room right now, there could  be a future Nobel Prize winner, a  Supreme Court Justice, an amazing  Mom. Find out who you are and don't  be afraid of it. (a beat) And if you'll all excuse me, I  have some business to take care  of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaction shots' all around. Kids start clapping, hollerin whooping. The MUSIC STARTS UP again. They all go back to  dancing The Denominators lead their own conga line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks around for Sam but he is gone. She runs out,  brushing past the Judges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge #2 dabs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This prom had it all. Laughter,  tears, an amazing climax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge #2, still overcome, just raises his "two thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie exits the club, looking for Sam. George runs up to  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey--I lost the feed! What happened  with Coulson? Gus is going crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the shadows emerges Sam. The look on his face says he just heard everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So--surprise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head in disbelief and walks off. Josie chas after him. He turns back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Surprise!" you were doing a story  on me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, surprise, I thought you'd be--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Happy? Why? Because it turns  out all along that I was allowed  to be attracted to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touched) You were attracted to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Josie! Drop the act. Do  you have any idea what I went  through every night because of  you?!  I was attracted to a 17  year old! When I wasn't taking  cold showers, I was trying to figure  out what the hell I was going to  do when I couldn't teach anymore!  I thought I was the one being  unethical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, I was going to tell you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You set me up. For a story. (beat) You know what's crazy? I was  actually considering waiting for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now you don't have to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I don't want to! I bought all  of your penguin crap. I thought I  found her--the right one! And the  problem was she was too young! No -  the problem was--she didn't even  exist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did exist. I do exist. I'm the  same person!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The person I cared about wouldn't  have done this. Everything out of  your mouth has been a complete  lie. I don't know you at all. For  all I know you could hate Dorothy  Parker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't! Look, you could get to  know me, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam turns and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Please don't walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't look at you the same  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam gets into his car and drives off. Josie is devastated

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, still in the prom dress, rounds the corner of her  apartment hallway and sees Rob, still in his Risky Busine get-up, slumped in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, finally. I just wanted to  come over and make sure you're  okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up. He's not happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No- not really, Josie. NOT REALLY.  How could you do that to me?  I  helped you. I got you everything  you wanted. And how do you repay  me- you blow everything TWO DAYS  before pro scouts come to see me  play. Once they had seen me really  play- they wouldn't have given a  shit about my age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wasn't even thinking about-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you weren't. Don't you realize  the only time I was really happy  in the last five years was when I  was playing ball with those guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, shut up, Josie. Just shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He storms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie lies amidst the needlepoint pillows, still in her  prom costume. She stares blankly at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus slaps a newspaper down on his desk. CLOSE ON - the front page of the paper, and not just any  newspaper - THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE - the Sun Times' rival. There is a PHOTO of Josie from Prom with the headline tha reads: "REPORTER REVEALED AT LOCAL HIGH SCHOOL". Josie picks it up, and starts reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your story was Rigfort's baby. We  were scooped! We've got nothing.  Zippo. You totally and completely  screwed both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could talk to Rigfort, you  know, tell him the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a story. It's about  this shy copy editor who makes a  mockery of herself and her boss  when she completely botches her  first assignment as a reporter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stands. Slams down the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not screwed. Yes, I made a  mistake. But we will have a story. (beat) You will have an amazing story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks out of Gus's office, continues, determined,  towards the elevators. Anita falls into step with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie! Josie, how'd it go? Did he  ream you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm okay. I've got some  work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need my help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks--I'm doing this on my  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks past Merkin's desk. She holds out her hand to Merkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merkin. Highlighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merkin slaps a highlighter into her hand, she continues  on. Anita watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie, looking quite the professional in stylish pantsuit and briefcase, bounds up the steps, two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie walks down the hall, purposefully - she is on a  mission. Groups of kids stop and stare at her, but this  time, Josie doesn't even notice. As Josie rounds a corner, she comes face to face with Guy who is at his locker. He looks at her. She smiles. And no it is Guy that is nervous. He drops a pile of papers, tri awkwardly to gather them. Josie looks at him - and for th first time we see it register on her face - this guy is  just a seventeen- year-old kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hey, umm--Ms. Geller. This is  totally embarrassing but my mom,  she's all worried about me getting  a job after graduation. She wanted  me to ask you about like, an  internship for me, at the Sun Times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do what I can. And tell your  mom not to worry - you'll do O.K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie continues down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys' locker room. A bunch of GUYS are getting dresse after P. E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN COMING THROUGH! COVER UP  WHAT YOU DON'T WANT SEEN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that Josie comes walking into the locker room,  completely unruffled, and storms over to Coach Romano's  office, just as he is leaving it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Coach Romano, my name is Josie  Geller, from the Chicago Sun Times  Listen, you know the local sports  guy for the Sun Times, Jim Lakin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, every coach in the area tries  to get Jim to cover his team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie puts her arm around the coach, and leads him back  into his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what would you say if I told  you that I could guarantee that  Jim and every other reporter in  the area would be at the game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say you can have whatever the  hell you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie smiles, together they enter his office and close th door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie sits at her disk, typing on her laptop, engrossed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone once told me that to write  well you have to write what you  know. This is what I know. I am  twenty five years old. I have never  really kissed a guy. A geek to the  core, most of my childhood years  were spent doing extra homework I  requested from the teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus comes in, snaps on the light, sits at his desk, and  opens his newspaper. He pulls out, the "Life and Style"  section. And there it is. Front page - "NEVER BEEN KISSED BY JOSIE GELLER."  There are three pictures next to the article.  One is Josie at age 17, one is her recent prom picture,  and one is her as a normal, 25 yr. old adult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school was more of the same.  Then, at seventeen, it seemed as  if my luck was about to change.  The cutest guy in school asked me  to senior prom - but it turned out  he invited me as a cruel joke. I  have never fully recovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita and Cynthia read the article, in the staff lunch  room, over a shared bag of microwave popcorn. They are  astounded-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is embarrassing to share  this with the world. But it would  be hard to explain what I learned,  and how I learned it, without  sharing this humiliating history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sun Times lies on the front mat. The door opens; we  see a pair of bare feet. A hand reaches down to grab the  paper. WE PAN UP to reveal Sam in all his depressed glory sweats, unshaven, bleary eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received an assignment, my first  as a reporter, to enroll in high  school as a student, to gain some  insight into kids today.  Understandably, returning to high  school was my worst nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids stream into school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I found?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Knox, wearing the sombrero, teaches her class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still that one teacher,  who marches to her own drummer-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in the back row, Kirsten, Kristen and Gibby are laugh an talking--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those girls are still there. The  ones that, even as you grow up,  will still be the most beautiful  girls that you've ever seen close  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The athletes - and the immense  sense of fraternity and loyalty  that they share-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smart kids. Who everyone else  always knew as the brains. But who  I just knew as my soulmates, my  teachers, my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's still that one guy,  the one who is so perfect in every  way, from the muscles in his  shoulders-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - to the way he, in his own way,  struggles to uphold tradition.   Southglen would not have been the  same without him. High school would  not be the same without him. I  would not have been the same without  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of these things made me  miserable at seventeen. But at  twenty five I finally see that  this - all of this- is just the  way it should be. It is all part  of this thing- high school. A time  in our lives that we can never  truly repeat.  A time that shapes  us. A time that makes us who we  are, for years to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High school- going through it the  first time- helped make me who I  am. But going there a second time  made me see that who I am is O.K.  I always wanted to be "in", but  seven years later, when they finally  opened the door, I somehow gained  the confidence to stay outside,  firmly, happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 75% of the people have their Life and Style section opened, reading Josie's piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the article I was sent  in to write. This is the article I  needed to write. I lived a lifetime  of regret after my first high school  experience, and now, after my  second, my regrets are down to  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen of a depressed guy--empty pizza boxes next to a dying plant. Sam pours milk into a bowl of Lucky Charms while he reads the Sports Section of the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A certain teacher was trampled in  my path to self-discovery, and  though this article may serve as a  step, it in no way makes up for  what I did to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not paying attention and the milk overflows the bowl soaking the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To this man, you know who you are,  I am so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the wet paper, using it like a sponge, he sops u the remaining milk, and throws the paper into an open tra can. He leaves the kitchen. WE HOLD ON the empty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, I would like to add one more  thing - I think I am in love with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cars begin to fill the parking lot in a steady stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I propose this - as an ending  to this article, and, perhaps, as  an ending to this portion of my  life. I, Josie Geller, will be at  the State Championship baseball  game В– where my friends the  Southglen Rams are playing for the  title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Southglen Rams baseball team minus Rob, are on the  field, warming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will stand on the pitcher's mound  for the five minutes prior to the  first pitch. If this man accepts  my apology, I ask him to come to  kiss me, in front of everyone, for  my first real kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find a nervous looking Josie standing in the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes may seem like a short  time, but trust me, when you've  been waiting twenty-five years,  it's usually the last five minutes  that kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went back to high school and  discovered I was a loser, again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN TO REVEAL the picture on the fridge in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam enters, still in sweats, carrying a book. He opens th fridge, grabs a beer, shuts it, is confronted by Josie's  picture. He takes it down, looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then I discovered it wasn't so  bad. I wasn't so bad. So, now that  I'm ready to start living the rest  of my life, it would be magical if  I could live the rest of it with  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam lets the photo slowly drop from his hand into the tra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because inside everyone is a loser  afraid to be loved, and out there  is the one person who can kiss us  and make it all better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FOLLOW Sam's stare down into the trash and see the pho lying on top and to the side of Josie's article--the phot from the article are clearly visible. ANGLE ON HOT DOGS, POPCORN CHANGING HANDS being sold by  the truckload at the stadium. The crowds are over capacit Way over. People fill the parking lot, they cover every  other inch of school grounds, as well. They stand on the  roofs of nearby buildings, they sit on top of their cars. It looks like most of Chicago is either already there, or on their way. Some WOMEN hold signs for Josie, others hold and wave her article. Josie sticks her head out of the dugout, and looks out at the fans. TV REPORTERS are everywhere, including several  on the field. She looks like she may faint. She ducks bac in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team is dressed, ready, excited. Anita and Aldys stan next to Josie. Josie looks up at the crowd, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. It's packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's great! They're behind you.  They feel like they know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's romantic, what you're doing,  and they want to be a part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm so glad that you guys  are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie then starts to hyperventilate. She puts her head  between her ankles. Anita and Aldys both grab the brown  paper bag and hand it to Josie. She hyperventilates into  it. Coach Romano approaches. Josie puts the bag down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus, Geller - I had no  idea there'd be all these TV crews  here. This thing's gonna be on  every station in the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie immediately begins hyperventilating into the bag  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You more than kept your end of the  bargain. Now go out there and get  'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie gets up and he slaps her on the ass. She hugs Aldys Then Anita gives Josie a big hug, and won't let go. Josie has to pull Anita pulls back. Josie struggles to get out  of the hug- Anita won't let her. Finally, they are both  laughing. Josie walks out of the dugout, and onto the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks, alone, out to the pitcher's mound, clutching a microphone. The crowd goes berserk. She stands until they quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have five minutes on the  clock, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scoreboard clock reads 5:00. Josie stands, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The staff from the Sun Times sits in box seats up front.  Rigfort joins them, carrying a huge load of hot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got weiners. Hot weiners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rigfort sits next to Gus. Behind them sit Bruns, his hair finally growing in and Howard, now down to just a sling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this. Sun Times readers,  out here, making a personal  connection to one of our reporters.  This is amazing, isn't it? Weiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus takes a weiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying his weiner) Wait a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rigfort pulls something small and shiny out of the bun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a bolt in my weiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he turns back to Howard and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Howard, what are you doing for  the next month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howard's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie still stands there. The clock is down to 2:30. She  looks over to the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Denominators talking and laughing. Behind them, sit  the Marching Band

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie forces-a stoic smile. 1:00 is on the clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cool crowd. Guy, Kirsten and the gang. They are tryin start the wave, but its not working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock reads: 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sun Times box. Anita clutches Gus's hand for dear lif has her eyes squeezed tight. The crowd keeps chanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone - including all the Denominators are on their  feet, chanting. Aldys cheers the loudest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are on their feet, chanting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy and the Gang are on their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stands, clutching the mic. The clock reads: 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEN - NINE - EIGHT - SEVEN - SIX -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie stands there, head still held high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIVE - FOUR - THREE - TWO -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie steals a look to the dugout. No one is coming out  the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie makes one more desperate look around. No one is  running toward her. CLOSE UP on Josie, completely crestfallen. She drops the  microphone. It reverbs in the silent stadium. WE PAN ACROSS the Crowd, all defeated. And then... A commotion in the stands. Sam bursts through the crowd.  He runs toward the mound. The Crowd is on their feet. It feels like a lifetime before he reaches Josie, grabs  her, pulls her close to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you you could write, Josie  Geller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finally found my story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they kiss passionately. The most amazing, most waited for kiss in the history of man. A kiss that will last  forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob is in his baseball uniform, cheering up a storm. Acro his chest is emblazoned: "ASSISTANT COACH".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anita is so thrilled, she reaches over and plants a big  one on Gus. She is surprised. So is he. They like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Denominators and Aldys cheer their brains out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy, Kirsten, etc. have finally succeeded in starting the wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: The Beach Boys "And Then I Kissed Her" as Josie and Sam continue to kiss as the CAMERA PULLS UP, taking i the kiss, the Crowd, the stadium... CAMERA SPINS UP as  FIREWORKS go off above the stadium... And we watch as the stadium becomes a speck against the glittering backdrop o Chicago.
